pages.title: MD2PDF Manual
pages.description: Complete MD2PDF manual. Learn how to convert Markdown to PDF quickly and for free.

intro: MD2PDF is a free Markdown to PDF converter with no limits and no signup required. Write in Markdown in the editor, preview in real-time in A4 format, and export directly to PDF.
In this manual you'll find everything you need to master the tool: from getting started to advanced export features and offline use.

sections.title: Why does your AI write like that?
content: If you've used ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini, or other AIs, you've probably noticed that responses come with strange symbols like **, #, -, and `.

infoBox.title: It's not a bug!
infoBox.text: These symbols are Markdown formatting - a simple language that transforms plain text into formatted documents.

contentAfter: Markdown was created to be readable even without rendering. That's why AIs use this format: it's universal, simple, and works anywhere.

steps.title: Copy the AI text
steps.text: Select the entire response from ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini, or any other AI and copy it (Ctrl+C).

steps.title: Paste in INPUT_STREAM
steps.text: Open MD2PDF and paste the text in the left editor.

steps.title: See the real-time preview
steps.text: The right panel instantly shows how your document will look formatted.

steps.title: Export to PDF
steps.text: Click the [ EXP_PDF ] button or use Ctrl+Shift+E.

sections.title: Next step
content: Now that you understand the basics, see What is Markdown to learn more about the format.

pages.title: What is Markdown
pages.description: Understand what Markdown is, its history, and why it's used everywhere from GitHub to AI responses.

sections.title: A Simple Formatting Language
content: Markdown is a lightweight markup language created by John Gruber in 2004. It allows you to add formatting to plain text using simple symbols.
Unlike HTML or Word documents, Markdown files are readable even without special software. This makes it perfect for documentation, notes, and content that needs to be portable.

sections.title: Where Markdown is Used
list: GitHub & GitLab: README files, issues, pull requests
AI Responses: ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini format their outputs in Markdown
Note-taking: Obsidian, Notion, Bear, and many others
Blogs: Jekyll, Hugo, and many static site generators

sections.title: Why Use Markdown?
list: Future-proof: No proprietary format to worry about

sections.title: Markdown vs HTML
content: Markdown is converted to HTML for display. You write # Title and it becomes <h1>Title</h1>.

sections.title: Headings
content: Use # to create headings. More # symbols = smaller heading level.

codeExample.code:
# Main Title (H1)
## Subtitle (H2)
### Section (H3)
#### Subsection (H4)
##### Smaller (H5)
###### Smallest (H6)
codeExample.description: H1 and H2 are most common. H3 and H4 are for subdivisions.

infoBox.title: Tip
infoBox.text: Always leave a space between # and the text. #Title won't work, use # Title.

sections.title: Text Formatting
content: Format words or phrases with symbols around the text.

sections.title: Line Breaks and Paragraphs
content: Markdown treats line breaks specially. Understanding this avoids frustration.

sections.title: Lists

codeExample.code:

- Item two

1. First item

sections.title: Basic Table Syntax
content: Create tables using | (pipe) and - (dash).

codeExample.code:
| Column 1 | Column 2 | Column 3 |
|----------|----------|----------|
| Data 1   | Data 2   | Data 3   |
| Data 4   | Data 5   | Data 6   |
codeExample.description: The second row with dashes separates the header from the body.

sections.title: Column Alignment
content: Use colons : to align column content.

codeExample.description: Mix alignments as needed for your data.

sections.title: Formatting in Tables
content: You can use Markdown formatting inside table cells.

infoBox.title: Tip
infoBox.text: Keep tables simple. Complex layouts may not render well in all viewers.

sections.title: Quick Table Insertion

sections.title: Inline Code
content: For code within a sentence, wrap with single backticks.

codeExample.description: Inline code is perfect for variable names, functions, or short commands.

sections.title: Code Blocks
content: For multiple lines of code, use three backticks (```) on separate lines.

codeExample.description: Everything between the backticks is rendered as code.

sections.title: Syntax Highlighting
content: Add the language name after the opening backticks for colored syntax highlighting.

codeExample.description: The language name enables proper color coding.

sections.title: Mermaid Diagrams
content: Create flowcharts, sequence diagrams, and more with Mermaid syntax. Diagrams are rendered automatically in the preview.

codeExample.code:
```mermaid
flowchart TD
  A[Start] --> B{Decision}
  B -->|Yes| C[Action]
  B -->|No| D[End]
```
codeExample.description: Use the MER button in Quick Tags to insert a template.

sections.title: YAML Blocks
content: YAML content is rendered with structured formatting - keys in bold, values in normal weight. Perfect for configuration files and metadata.

codeExample.code:
```yaml
name: My Project
version: 1.0.0
config:
  debug: true
  features:
    - auth
    - logging
```
codeExample.description: Use the YML button in Quick Tags to insert a template.

pages.description: Solutions to common problems with MD2PDF: PDF issues, formatting, offline mode, and more.
pages.keywords: troubleshooting, problems, issues, help, faq, md2pdf help

infoBoxes.title: PDF looks different from preview?
infoBoxes.text: Make sure browser zoom is at 100%. Check print settings: margins, scale, background graphics.

infoBoxes.title: Extra blank pages?
infoBoxes.text: Check for extra --- in your content. Each creates a page break.

infoBoxes.title: Images not showing in PDF?
infoBoxes.text: Use direct image URLs (https://). Local file paths won't work in PDF.

infoBoxes.title: Markdown not rendering?
infoBoxes.text: Check for spaces: # Title needs space after #. **bold** needs no spaces inside.

infoBoxes.title: Documents disappeared?
infoBoxes.text: Did you clear browser data? Use a different browser? Documents are per-browser.

infoBoxes.title: Can't save (MEM full)?
infoBoxes.text: Export old documents and delete them to free space.

infoBoxes.title: Private/Incognito mode?
infoBoxes.text: Documents may not persist. Use regular mode.

infoBoxes.title: App not working offline?
infoBoxes.text: Visit the app online first to cache it. Then offline will work.

infoBoxes.title: Can't install as PWA?
infoBoxes.text: Only works on HTTPS. Use Chrome, Edge, or Safari.

infoBoxes.title: App not updating?
infoBoxes.text: Clear site data and reload, or wait for auto-update.

sections.title: Still having issues?
content: Check that you're using a modern browser (Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Safari). Clear cache and reload the page. Most issues are resolved by a fresh start.
